text: Orville Huntington earned his Bachelor of Science in Wildlife Biology from the University of Alaska, Fairbanks. Participating on many professional panels, Orville Huntington currently works as the Chair of the Interior Athabascan Tribal College, a Refuge Information Technician at the Koyukuk/Nowitna NWR , a Vice Chairperson for the Alaska Native Science Committee (since 2000), and the Interior Villages Representative on the Alaska Federation of Natives Board for the 43 villages in the Doyon area. Furthermore, he is dedicated to promoting Native American Traditional Ecological Knowledge by integrating local and traditional knowledge with western science. Mainly, his research analyzes how a subsistence lifestyle directly impacts fish, animals, and plants of Northern ecosystems. == Research contributions == Huntington has been the lead or contributing author on several publications that focus on the relationships between traditional or indigenous knowledge and Western science. The focus of several articles is climate change adaptations and the ways that indigenous expertise and spiritual, ethical practices contribute to an understanding of ecosystems. In addition, the research offers an interdisciplinary perspective that speaks to the intersections of tribal knowledge, spiritual traditions, and wildlife management and regulations. == References == * Alaska Native Science Committee (nd).
